interconnection.net_metering_details: Hawaii ended traditional net metering in 2015. Replaced with Customer Grid-Supply (CGS) and Customer Self-Supply (CSS) programs. Smart Export program pays time-varying export rates (approx 10-15 cents/kWh). Battery storage strongly incentivized for self-consumption. HECO, MECO, and HELCO handle interconnection.
interconnection.fees: Interconnection application fee varies; $50-$250 typical for residential

special_considerations.hoa_restrictions: Strong solar access law (HRS 196-7). Prohibits preventing solar installation on single-family dwellings or townhouses. One of the earliest solar access laws in the nation.
special_considerations.historic_districts: Historic districts in Honolulu (Chinatown, Capitol District) and other areas may require additional review. State Historic Preservation Division consulted.
special_considerations.wind_load_requirements: Hurricane zone requirements apply statewide. Design wind speeds 105-130 mph depending on island and exposure category. Compliance with IBC hurricane provisions required.
special_considerations.snow_load_requirements: Not applicable for most areas. Mauna Kea summit area has snow but no residential installations.

licensing.license_type: C-60 Solar Energy Contractor license or licensed General Contractor (automatically includes solar). Electrical work requires licensed electrician.

notes: Hawaii has the highest electricity rates in the nation ($0.35-0.45/kWh), making solar extremely attractive even without net metering. The state has the highest per-capita solar adoption rate. Grid saturation on some islands has caused interconnection delays and curtailment. Battery storage is increasingly required for new installations to manage grid impacts. 100% renewable energy mandate by 2045. Unique island grid challenges not found in mainland states.
